addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord
e L. Burghley Lord high Treasurer of England

30 Sep
t
1591
M
r
Bodeleie from
e Haghe to my L./

page.lettertext:
fol.57r
May it please yo
r
good L. sins
e writing of
my last
e 9 of this moneth, there hath no-
thing passed in this place in any mater of con-
sultation, or othe r forrene occurrence, that I
could thinke might deserve to be reported to
yo
r
L. As touching
Hulst
I dyd assure
my self that her
Ma
ties
ministers, w
ch
were pre-
sent at
e enterprise, wold advertise sufficiently.
And
e winde being Esterly, there was meanes
for their letters to come sooner to yo
r
L. then
hither to
e Hage. Not only
Zeland,
whiche
was most of all annoied by
e land of Waes,
but
e generallitie of these contreis shall re-
ceave a great commoditie by
e conquest of
that place. The present summe, wherunto
e contrey about Hulst hath yelded for a
monethly contribution, is towardes 800
li
ster
l
w
ch
after a while it is thought, they may easely
raise to triple as muche. Moreover they have
given hostages for
e paiment of 7000
li
ster
l
w
t
in
e space of a moneth, to redeeme their contrey
from
e spoile of
e souldiers. In
e towne it
self of Hulst
e self same order is taken, for
e
paiment of Impost and Accise and other pub-
like taxes, as they were put unto before, by
order of
e Enemie: w
ch
are greater unto
them, then are usually imposed, upon
e inha-
bitants of these contreis.
Count
Maurice
hath concluded w
t
e
Councel of state
to returne againe to
Nieumeghen.
For by all
advertisments, aswell from
e contrey about it,
fol.57v
as from some w
t
in
e towne, there miserie is
suche, and so likely to increase, as they can not
in reason but yelde er be long. And besides
we have secret frindes w
t
in
e towne in nomber
sufficient, when
e campe is come before it, to
make a faction w
t
in, w
ch
they doe promise to doe
effectually, and assure us in a maner to be
masters of
e place. The rendevous of the
states
forces is assigned
e 1 of October, at
e
fort of
Cnossenbourgh,
whiche is overagainst
Nieumeghen. The exploit, it is thought, will
be quickly at an end, for w
ch
the Councel of state
doth not purpose to goe hens. We
all
are alwaies heere so ill provided of intelli-
gence of
e Enemie, as we knowe no other cer-
taintie of his going for
France,
then
e bruit of
e
people, w
ch
is
e same
at it hath bin,
at he goeth
undoubtedly. Nevertheles there are many men
heere of an other opinion, that he wanteth men
and mony to serve his turne in bothe respectes,
to give a roial assistance to
e
D. de Mainne
,
and to defend himself at home. For nowe
at
he is touched by
e states w
t
an offensive
warre, his weakenes is many waies very no-
tabley discovered: and especially his ignor
a
ce
in
e state of these contreis, aswell in regard
of
e strength of their forces,
and
as of
e na-
ture and site of their townes and places.
Heerof we are daily more assured, not only
by those courses, w
ch
he hath taken all this somer,
but by divers letters intercepted, and chiefly
nowe of late by certaine neutral persons, men
fol.58r
of very good judgement, w
ch
have conversed w
t
e chiefest of
e Enemies, and finde by all their
discourses, that ether God hath taken their un-
derstanding from them, or they were never well
informed of
e state of thinges w
t
us.
The Empero
rs
Late intent, to persuade w
t
the
states, to treat about a peace is revived againe.
His Ambassado
rs
meete in
Collen
e 5 of
e next
from whens they goe towardes
Brussels,
and if
their purpose take place, from thens into
Holland.
Of this designe we understand by sundrie mens
Letters: but by one in speciall, w
ch
is newly sent
hither to one
Mons
r
Sonsfeld
, a right honest gen-
tleman, and an ancient servant to Count Maurice,
from
Otto Henry de Bilandt Baron of Reide
in
e Land of
Cleve
, who is cousin to
e gentleman,
and one of those Ambassado
rs
. The substance
of his letter is to persuade w
t
Mons
r
Sonsfeld
being heere in good credit, to make himself an
instrument for procuring
e Count and
e states
to Hearcken to a peace. He promiseth great
rewardes and accesse of dignities, to Count
Maurice by name, to
Barnevelt,
to
e partie
himself, and to as many of
e state, as are
nowe in autoritie, and shall doe their endevo
r
,
to further
e treaty. As touching maters of
religion, he himself doth professe to be wholy
reformed, and in his owne jurisdiction to main-
tene
e same religion, as is autorised heere in
e
United Provinces
: wherupon he would inferre
that his meaning his sincere. And if in those
fol.58v
causes
e Empero
r
and
e states should not
come to a good agreement, that then
e pointes
in difference shall be decided by certaine arbiters,
to be chosen indifferently of
e Princes of
e Em-
pire, and of bothe religions. And for
e pollicie
of their state, they shall enjoye their ancient
rightes, immunities and privileges, in as ample
and free condition, as at any time heeretofore.
This is
in
effect
e contents of his letter, wherew
t
Count Maurice acquainted me presently, and
imparted it after to
e Councel of state.
But there needed nothing to be said for dissuading
any one, to give eare to suche treaties. For they
were wonderfull carefull to suppresse
e letters
that no copies might be taken: w
ch
was also an
occasion
at I could not as I would, send a
transcript to yo
r
L. Moreover they deli-
vered Mons
r
Sonsfeld
e argument of his
answear, to be made as from himself: wher-
in he should declare,
at nether
e chiefest go-
verno
rs
, nor
e commons of
e contrey, would
ether accept of their Ambassade, or give any
audience or accesse to any
at were sent, or pro-
mise safetie to their persons, from
e outrage
of
e people. The rest
at are named
to be imploied by
e Empero
r
, besides
e for-
said Baron, are not signified in his letter, but
by other advertisements I learne
at they are
these, The
Seign
r
of Barenstein
, The
Count of Lipp
,
Salentinus of Issenburch
, w
ch
was Bishop of
Collen
before Truxes,
Docto
r
Faber
, and
e brother of
e bishop of Witzburch.
fol.59r
For mine owne particular, I will use in this
mater all maner of vigilance, and as occasion
is presented, I will put yo
r
L. cautions in
practise w
ch
were sent me heeretofore, in whiche
I purpose to proceede, as to my understanding
shall be most expedient for
e service of her Ma
tie
.
And so I take my humble leave.
From
e Hage. Sep
t
30 1591.
Yo
r
L most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley.
